as a as an option that has two choices for you that results somewhat in the same resources that are available to you

between them can have you know a much higher performance than if if not so
because when we look for a placement group for you we basically look at how many of the or can we fulfill the request for all the instances you need

what enhanced networking allows you to do is to drive down the the network and latency jitter that you

one of the performance or one of the benefits of ebs is the fact that it's persistent so you can attach an ebs volume to an instance and you can

resources again and the storage persists on dbs volume and then you have different options for ebs volumes you
have magnetic volumes that are very very cost effective you have general purpose ssd volumes that can
support more needy or iops needy workloads and then you have provisioned iops that just can get you consistent
large iops performance the entire time so the great news about eds is you can
right size it depending on how much storage you actually need you can select the type of vbs volume you actually need

not evenly distributed for a lot of the workloads that you have a lot of times if it's something that's customer facing it will be something
that maybe just starts scaling up in the morning and in this case you know this is obviously the random part it it peaks at noon it might be something else
depending on what type of application you're running and then it comes back down so we have 24 hours
within a day and then we have a load that comes in kind of peaks and then comes back down so if we just arbitrarily say okay these
two units of server load can be managed by one one capacity or the capacity of one
server then what we would have to traditionally do is we have to provision for peak capacity because we want to
make sure that you know as we have all these customers coming in they don't get a degraded performance this is where we
really uh show our value to our customer this is where we really want to make them happy actually you know and this is
even conservative because if you think about it are you really provisioning right there do you actually know where your peak is and what do you do if you
have hardware failure so then in reality we would see things like you know people not having two servers in the data
center or under their desk or whatever it might be but three or four but what you can do with ec2 is that you
can react to your demand or the demand you're seeing on the fly by provisioning additional servers in
the cloud so in ec2 land it would basically look like this you have a server running for the first eight hours
then you have two servers running as you provision for peak and then you scale back down and this is a pretty simple
example but it can show you sort of you know this would be in the the peak to valley here by the way is really not
extravagant or anything like that it's actually pretty conservative but it shows you that in a scenario like this
you can have 33 savings just for the fact that you're elastic now and not only that you can actually if you have
an unforeseen peak you can react to that as well and you can have a better customer experience so elasticity kind of helps
you you know on the performance side as well as on the on the cost side now again like i said this is in some
ways a conservative estimate let's say this these wouldn't be one and two servers this would be 100 and 200 you
can have incremental changes as you see here the orange area is actually covering some of the area above the
server load so if you can incrementally go from 100 to 200 you can squeeze out even more savings that said you probably
want to stay you know somewhere within a safety range above your load just to make sure that the last customer coming
in has the same performance that you expect for everyone to have this is another example
again not extreme and and pretty powerful in that it doesn't only show elasticity and cost savings but also

payroll or we do some sort of batch processing what happens traditionally is you know if you have a monthly
predictable peak again you plan for peak so you have this much capacity that you

other one has a small likelihood of being affected at the same time and you can take advantage of that and you can
